commentBody:
Garrett may be at the U, 
but will the natives protest 
the "extra" letter in the 103A entry?  

It needs to be HOT L BALTIMORE,
but that wasn't in Chicago.
Happy 10th crossword my love!! Endlessly proud <3

While this was a very easy puzzle, I really enjoyed solving it, because most of the wacky bisections of the last word made me smile or even occasionally chuckle.  A good puzzle is sometimes more about providing a pleasant diversion than wracking one’s brain.

I wonder when my comment 
approved five minutes ago 
will show up here...
Good puzzle overall, though not a fan of so many abbreviations. I call foul having IMED and DMED appear in the same puzzle.

I don't see how RAGS is an appropriate response to pauperism. I can't find a dictionary that defines a "rag" as an impoverished person. And crossing with INXS and MRSWHO was no help. Another Natick with AEANAS and SAWEETIE

Avocets/Beaucoup tripped me up a bit.

One of those puzzles where you had to sit with it, come back to it, then it comes together. The best type of puzzling.

Excellent. Really, really excellent. Inventive, spunky, and energetic. You know how when electrons enter an excited state, they zigzag around like mad? That’s what this puzzle did for my neurons. 

Did I mention this was an excellent puzzle?
I thought the theme was silly, until after I finished and actually read the title. That and "STAIRS" for [Way up or way down] elicited an audible chuckle from me. Thanks for the wordplay Garrett!

Great puzzle! As always, hampered by US-specific things, but getting better.
Had fun with the SW corner: not au fait with lumberjack things or MLB royalty, I had EMIR for a prince, giving BLUES for the doldrums. Love those fun alternatives!
Fresh and clever. Pas de sweat.

I didn’t read the title, but the penny dropped pretty quickly with GRAND RAP IDS. However, it wasn’t until I finished and read the title that the amazing symmetry was revealed for me. I was just enjoying the silliness of the word play.

So clever.

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review of Garrett Chalfin's amusing puzzle: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/05/17/sunday-may-18-2025/ Just a reminder that DoCF covers several puzzles each day, including the LAT, WSJ, WaPo (Sundays only), Universal, USA Today and BEQ. If you solve any of those puzzles, stop by Fiend and say "hi."

The cross of SAWEETIE and AENEAS, Holy Mother of Zeus and St. Francis. I really, really wanted a clean solve.  I had SuWEETIE and AENEuS.

Just an brutal cross for my background.   The puzzle seemed a bit rap heavy. I about threw in the towel with 23A.

But I thought the theme was hilarious.  Everyone of them was a delight, especially LOVEHOTEL.

Does anyone know the difference between IMED and DMED, both of which appeared today?

96A.   I should try to remember that any piece of apparel I don't recognize must have something to do with a bra.

If there is ever an architect with three of five letters that *isn't* PEI or IMPEI, I'm in trouble.
I finally got the hot El train reference!
A clever theme, but with some iffy clues (e.g., CAPE, BEAR, RAVE), and too heavy on slang and pop culture for my taste.
I liked it. A bit too much rap or hip hop or whatever its called now (I won't say what I call it).

Ooohwee!! I definitely would not call that breezy, unless breezy has a definition I don't understand, which is certainly possible, as I've learned out here many times. Anyhow, it was quite hard for me. There were several times where I had crossings that I just did not think I was going to manage without lookups. 

Somehow I did manage without but I was a little bit weary of it in the end and was getting close to doing a reveal for the last few crosses because I'm ready to move on to watching the next couple episodes of The Residence. Woman cannot live on puzzles alone, after all!

Still, I kept at it a little longer because I haven't had to reveal or use help in a good while and I'd like to keep it that way.  It was just a lot that was out of my wheelhouse. Definitely a slower than average one.

Anyhow, I enjoyed the theme and the fun entries. My favorite was WHATSTHEDAMAGE, followed by LOVEHOTELS.  Figuring out the theme fairly early on when the dam one came to me quickly, certainly helped me quite a bit in getting some of the tough for me fill. 

Anyhow, it's now martiniOCLOCK so off to Netflix we go!
Best puzzle by a dam cite.

One who is against squishing the bug on the sidewalk ????

 antidepressant
Good tough Sunday

Working through the archive, I’ve solved a lot of crosswords with themes similar to this one’s, but more often than not the wordplay has been lame.

This, though, was fun and funny. Congratulations to Mr. Chalfin!

Loved the theme, the halving. Very clever! Fave = Groucho. Did not love IM/DM in the same puzzle (ugh) and, as others have said, too many rap/pop culture references (not Boomer friendly) but I solved via the crosses anyway.

I found this Sunday puzzle both clever and groanworthy.  I guess Home Alone is an example of MAKINGANIMPACT.  I had chest for trunk which made that little section at the bottom tougher than it should have been, until I   found TORSO.

Bonus points for including AVOCET, perhaps our most beautiful and graceful wading bird. I spent a few years splitting time between Ardmore and San Diego, and one of the great joys of spending time in SD was living walking distance from a spot reliably frequented by AVOCETS in season.

A classical observation about Aeneas.  Since i know of him mainly through the Roman version of his history, as founder of Rome and imputed ancestor of Caesar, i have always identified his mother by her Roman identity: Venus. Of course, seeing that he existed originally in Greek legend, Homer, the clue is perfectly fair, just for a moment misdirecting.
Before I looked at the length, I thought the answer to 38D might be TLC, who also have a song called “Creep,” so it was great to see that answer appear elsewhere in the puzzle. Coincidence?
I learned [Dad, in Korean] by watching KIMSCONVENIENCE. Fun to be able to effortlessly drop both entries in this weekend. I expect to see UMMA on Monday, for the full cycle.
Great puzzle.

The main clues were great - the fillers were nasty, RBG, BIALY, ALAI, BAIUL, SAWTEE, ALOU, LETO, CIAO, IMPEI, APPA, PESCI, TYRA, HAP?, TIG, EHUD, RHODA,DQED, ROLEO, PETCO, USMA, ARO, that is not all of them, SCREW was the first clue I entered thanks DEB :)
Ah well tomorrow is another day.

I think some of you are ahead of me on this, but I'm trying to get around the forum bug by replying *only* to the OP.

I just change the @originalPoster to @personIamReplyingTo

A lot (all?) of the "missing" comments are replies to another reply in the same thread.

Poor form.  "Alou" is one of the bits of tedious sports trivia that did not make it into my head over the last few decades.  Never heard of them.  And this crosses "roleo" which (while a funny coinage) I imagine that effectively no one has heard of.  A sports Natick, the very worst kind.

Other than that, and all the questionable fill others have noted, it was an okay Sunday.  The theme was cute and easy.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Definitely groan-worthy, which I greatly appreciated. Especially liked the DAM AGE and HOT ELS answers, but MUST ACHE and IMP ACT were winners as well. The title was very helpful and it clicked with the first themer.

A fun one! Thanks, Garret!

Fun solve! I liked DAM AGE best.

I always spell it BIALI for some reason and I always have to circle back and fix it.

The answer CAPE had me thinking the trick was going to be that COD was hidden somewhere. I guess you're supposed to infer which one.

Hope everyone has a nice Sunday.
This puzzle really made me feel like 84D...

I loved the theme and the clever wordplay.

Still, too many obscure (to me) words and references made this a tough journey. RECTO, BIALY, APPA, EHUD, AVOCETS and OLLAS were just a few of my roadblocks. I was able to guess/ force my way past all of those, but it was the letter linking A_OU and RO_EO that made me finally give up and —quite literally— take the L.

I guess you could say I admired this puzzle more than I enjoyed it.

Garrett, that was well done for the goal of testing brute knowledge. I yield. 

I look forward to seeing where your creativity will lead you.

I keep making the mistake of attempting Sunday grids... I used to enjoy them in the past but recently I haven't had any fun with them, at all. I must remember my own advice next week: skip Sunday, Andrzej! The theme... There was an element of wit to it, I suppose, but generally I perceived it as yet another set of groaners. Can't a Sunday theme be truly smart, for once? The puzzle was notable for featuring my wife's and mine least favorite artists. She can't stand RADIOHEAD, and my ears bleed when I hear LETO's 30 Seconds to Mars: it's one of the few bands I have blacklisted on Spotify 🤣 Of course I was clueless about most of the names and abbreviations, as always. I also did not understand other terms in either the clues or answers. Some of them: Verso? RECTO? Bandeau? HAP? OLLAS? I had LEIs for luau strings, and I was so proud of it! Before I started doing NYT puzzles, all I knew of Hawaiian terms was, predictably, aloha. ALAS... The first thing to come to my mind when I see the name OLD TOWN is of course the one in Warsaw. As a kid I loved its narrow streets and quaint houses. In a way it's only some 25-30 years older than me, however. It was completely destroyed by the Germans during WW2, as were 90% of the city's buildings on the West bank of the Wisła (Vistula). It was reconstructed in the 1950s so meticulously it was then given UNESCO World Heritage status. Here is a 90 second video showing some before and after images: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Gu7PY2mzgto

Nice one. You know I'm going to be using some of these just to confuse my friends.
Like others said, however, IM and DM in the same puzzle, hmmm. One of the funny things about current references is that you never know how long they'll last, they could age out by next year, could take a decade. I mean, if you too back through the archives (I started going backwards a few years ago, hit 20 years back this week) you'll come across so many things that don't exist anymore (Napster, ipods, etc.) And pop culture references that are best forgotten, perhaps.
There's also a puzzle from 1942 on the website, that was really tough with the people, places and things that people were expected to know then. Autocheck on.

Mini crossword comment without the spoiler. At Oktoberfest, it being held in Bavaria, you drink a maß and no one to my knowledge uses the term this puzzle is so fond of. https://de.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ma%C3%9Fkrug

@Deb
I’ll take “literary trivia” over rap/rock group trivia 24/7.
Why does NYT fail to provide the title for online solvers?

Nice one! I must have read and said the word 'salesperson' thousands of times but never once factored it into 'sales per son'. This is some fine crossword puzzle alchemy at work: selecting a mundane term and transforming it into something new, shiny, and surprising.
I still didn't understand the theme even when I got GRANDRAPID. Not until MAKINGANIMPACT. Not too hard after that, but this was a really fun, memorable crossword. More of these please!

I quite enjoyed this puzzle, and its theme. One clue, however, I reject: Groucho Marx is not a “co-star” of DUCK SOUP, he is one of the stars, and in fact, of course, the principal star. For over a century in Hollywood, “co-star” is a lower rank — for example, Eric Blore or Edward Everett Horton in Fred Astaire movies.
Why is a "gnarly problem" a bear?

A decent solve for the euro contingent, excepting BIALY and the Americana cross of death ROLEO/ALOU (who I will file next to mel OTT in the prehistoric baseball players crossword answer folder).

Thanks for another enjoyable Sunday and have a great day everyone :)
Generous of the setter to include so many people I like to publicly bash in the grid with that clue

I thought the themed entries were so clever and funny (apart from the rap one - was it just me?)
However.
So many words I'd never seen before, slang I'd never heard before, 'general knowledge' I didn't know, people who were strangers to me - I won't list them, others have done it for me.

I did go through and reveal them all, because of being useful in the future. 
You win some ....

Twenty five minutes searching for the mistake.  Pesce are fish, not an actor.

Otherwise, a good Sunday challenge.
I concur with other commenters that there were too many rap/rock references. I realize that this hugely important to a newly graduating collegian but to the rest of us it is obscure trivia.

Loved the themed answers, but wasn’t crazy about a lot of the fill. I picked up on the theme on the first entry with GRAND Puba / GRAND Daddy IU and thought it was a great feat to split the last word of the themed answers into two evenly split words. Well done Mr. Chalfin.

These theme answers are not easy to come by.  
•	The last word of the answer must have an even number of letters.
•	Each half of that word must be a word in its own right.
•	That word must conclude an in-the-language phrase.

Whew!  So, say, you come up with a word like HIPPIE that can break into HIP and PIE, and a hip pie can be a thing, maybe even a funny thing.  But then you have to find a common phrase that ends with HIPPIE and can make sense with “hip pie”.  And I, at least, haven’t.  So, back to the drawing board.

Here, Garrett came up with seven – seven!  Furthermore, they fit the letter-count requirements of symmetry.  High props for that!

I got in a good mood right from the start, when BAIUL popped out, a figure-skating name lying dormant in my brain for some 30 years.  The mood escalated when I uncovered MAKING AN IMP ACT – Hah!  It continued to rise as some swaths filled in with a splash, while others made me do delicious work.  

Garrett, your creation was clever, fun, and satisfying.  Thank you for a splendid outing!

What a fun, breezy puzzle.  Each of the themers gave me a chuckle, but MAKING AN IMP ACT was my favorite.  

When I was working as a massage therapist, I had a client who participated in ROLEOs and was a high-level birler (log roller), so that went right in.  

One of the things I liked best about that job was the diverse clientele I had the opportunity to interact with.  I worked on nuns, sex workers, orthopedic surgeons, clowns, accountants, HOTEL maids, musicians and people with hobbies from BASE jumping to stamp collecting.  Spending an hour each week or so in such a private setting often got them talking, and I learned so much from them.  

Occasionally, that knowledge helps with crossword puzzles.
I must be a dope.  I don't get 103 across.

I really appreciate a puzzle where the themed answers are so thoughtful and fun, as well as clever. For me it clicked at MAKE AN IMP ACT. Great job, Garrett

Another reminder that it is Mental Health Awareness Month, since OCD is an answer in today’s puzzle.
OCD is something that has been made light of, but it is really not a laughing matter. I suffered from debilitating OCD when I was younger. In one of its many manifestations, I would go back and check my front door dozens of times to make sure I had locked it. I didn’t go out much, it was too exhausting. Fortunately, I have worked through my anxiety for the most part and enjoy a fairly normal life. 
I cringe when I hear people use the term casually and/or callously.

Whew. And Wow. Pretty amazing puzzle - one where the trick is all in the clues. Good long workout for me and I was appropriately puzzled for a bit even after I had worked out a couple of theme answers from the crosses. But then just a jaw-dropping 'aha' moment when it all finally dawned on me. Kind of odd but appropriate puzzle find today. This was another one with a trick that I don't recall ever seeing before. Pretty amazing piece of construction. This one had straightforwardly clued theme answers that all had RX embedded in the answers, and those shifted symmetrically left to right from top to bottom and connected two corner answers - upper left and lower right, which were: SICK and WELL The answer that got me there was the only other appearance of.... GROUCHOMA(RX)MUSTACHE in another puzzle. Some other theme answers: XE(RX)ESOFPERSIA FOU(RX)FOUR THEWINTE(RX)GAMES PROFESSO(RX)AVIER SOLVEFO(RX) RETURNOFDOCTO(RX) And the title of the puzzle was: "It's better this way." Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/16/2014&g=65&d=A ....

This was a lot of fun.

Some of the themers fell into place before I knew why, but I eventually saw them all. Very cleverly constructed.

Probably more than the usual number of rappers and other pop culture figures I'd never heard of, but that's just something to live with.

Beat my average, so Sunday is off to a good start.
Was ITCHY part of the themed answers? If not, a spent a long time trying to figure out how to halve that word and it shouldn’t have been a question marked clue!
IMAMORON! Great Sunday puzzle.

Almost made it through the morass of names and trivia, but failed at the crossing of SAWEETIE and AENEAS. Went with SUWEETIE and AENEUS. And another short streak bites the dust. Everything else was filled correctly, with no assistance (but rather slowly).

For me, the theme just wasn't worth it. Cute enough, but the price paid in my loss of enjoyment at having to conjure up name after name was just too much. 

Took me a long while to get RAGS/VERGE, but in the end those made some sense. Wild guess with MRSWHO. Never heard of ROLEO; had ROLLS (as in log-rolling) for some time. 

IMED, PMED, DQED ... oh well.

A moderate Sunday, I thought. Beyond the theme, I appreciated a few crosses: PEEK/LEEKS; VERGE; VIRGIL. I admit…before yesterday, I did not remember hearing of LOVE HOTELS, but coincidentally I was reading Murakami’s “UFO in Kushiro” in A Century of Fiction in the New Yorker, which I’m reading at the rate of a story a day, and Murakami’s final scene occurs in one, then, last night when I’m starting the crossword, voila! There’s 103A as part of the theme. The serendipity made me laugh. Sure, I know the concept…here in St. Louis where I live we had, for the longest time, a rather famous (infamous?) establishment, Coral Court, which featured separate garages for each unit, access to the room from the garage. The buildings were actually quite beautiful (art deco) and so even if one never used the establishment, it was quite sad when they tore it down 30 years ago, though someone did dismantle a unit and rebuild it at the National Museum of Transportation. Looking it up just now, I see it was infamous for another reason…in the fifties, police arrested one of the kidnappers in the Bobby Greenlease case there.
Isn't the Grand Puba the head of the Loyal Order of Water Buffalo, the lodge of Fred Flintstone and Barney Rubble?

Here in the UK, long ago, we used to have a lovely TV programme entitled "One Man And His Dog", in which hill shepherds and their dogs competed to move sheep around in very precise ways.
I tell you this because the first time I saw ROLEO on TV, I thought it should be called "One Man And His Log."

(And, yes, women are involved in both activities. We're going back a few years, and the chance to play with a line from the children's "... Went To Mow" song seems to have trumped any impulse to find a gender-neutral title for the shepherding contest.)

Anyway, that's how ROLEO became a gimme for me today.
Loved MAKING AN IMP ACT - excellent puzzle!

You know you are getting old when ...

the caption for a photo of Laurel and Hardy needs to include "a comedy duo".

Got it!  It wasn't that difficult, but it sure was LOooooong!  And I was in a Double Natick with _A Wrinkle in TIme_, a Band from 1987, and "Pauperism."  I had _ AG_ and finally figured it out with that last clue, but it was the final entry in the (seemingly endless) puzzle.  
It must have taken Quite A While for Garrett to come up with that many themers!  Wow.  
I note that OLLA is  still not "a word" to the Beekeeper.  Today's endless Bee blithely ignores a good-sized list even after admitting (at long last) a sailing term that has been spurned for some years now.  
Anyone else think that a "bandeau" dispenses with the BRAsiere entirely?  (I know, I know, but I had to try it...)

Hope those in the path of the tornado activity (Kentucky and Missouri, especially) are surviving.  We had most of the day devoted to a seemingly endless series of thunderstorms, with at least one strike that rattled the windows.  Just as the rivers had started to go down....

"Virgil Cain is my name..." and I am a literary reference buried in a pop song.

Agree with Barry A. you can get the rap, etc. performers from the crosses but they can be off putting to those of us who are old and in the way.

Thank you Garrett

[The highest number of oniony bread rolls one can store?]







MAX BIALYSTOCK

This was tremendously entertaining - all very cute themers and some (WHAT'S THE DAMAGE and SALESPERSON, for example) I'll giggle over for the rest of the day. 

Also wanted to agree that MRSWHO would be incredibly difficult if you've not read A Wrinkle in Time - but if you haven't, please from the bottom of my bachelor's-degree-in-children's-literature heart give it a try. It doesn't read like a kids' book or particularly like science fiction or fantasy, all things it's generally classified as and two of which I don't usually particularly like. It's... lovely. Lovely and thoughtful and just an excellent read. I actually like Wind in the Door, which follows it, even better, but Wrinkle is the one to start with. MRSWHO - and her friends Mrs. Which and Mrs. Whatsit and of course Meg and Calvin and Charles Wallace - are literary companions of the highest possible order. 

Wishing everyone a happy (and safe) Sunday.
Simply wonderful.
Just the kind of dumb puns I like; but I have never heard of a Roleo.
Got there in the end but there was just too much junk fill for this to be enjoyable for me
Rock group with the 1992 hit "Creep"? I refuse to believe this was 33 years ago.
Meh.  Decent theme; well below avg time but a solid 30% of that was spent on the various combinations of aene_s / S_weetie and mrswh_/ _llas.  23A “master flash” would have been kinder.
Blech

I enjoyed the whole experience rightfully so, after giving 1:27:44 of my Sunday morning to it That's about right for me anyway. A cuber, I am not, nor am I Cuban. @Caitlin Lovinger The theme didn't really click for me, even having checked the title numerous times. The themed answers were even more clever than the clues. Great job Garrett!! I really enjoy a good college student’s mind at work. Appa just won't go away, will it? Cuddle puddles - gosh, I need to get out more "Wonder Woman" star - Love me some Gal, but Lynda is OG (not one g). Note to self, ask Tig about an aro. Not familiar with a bandeau. Costanza never mentioned it in his interview for bra sales, so must not be too, too important(?) 38D - I had to laugh for two reasons. #1, I briefly gigged with a local band where the “other” guitar player, much younger than I, screamed in this song waaay too much. #2, the Hipsters or Homeles quiz Max Black gave Han… classic! https://youtu.be/NEX51zsxy9A?si=lahywjwjjOme6nx1 Not to be outdone by her Coldplay reference to the finger-snapping hipsters. https://youtu.be/Kr5-fcZ2sWY?si=HnR_fk7w2dr5Wu6N Enjoyed it immensely!

I consider a Friday, Saturday, or Sunday puzzle a success for me personally if I hit fewer than 10 lookups, just a fun little personal goal I have. I had 8 today so still achieved my goal, was just amused that I only had 2 until I hit the northwest corner which was SUCH a bear for me to break into! Cute theme and lovely Sunday, hope everyone has a wonderful day :)
Kinda cute

Thoroughly proper Sunday requiring bits of knowledge spanning decades, and a good sense of humor. 
I got COFFEEOCLOCK right away, since I was doing it with my precious morning brew in my hand. If it was afternoon, I'd still be sitting here wondering why wineOCLOCK doesn't fit!

And with that, my streak hits FIVE YEARS. 

Whoa.

Yeah. Didn’t hate this, didn’t love it. Don’t know why; the theme was ok. Puns aren’t my cup of tea but that’s ok. 

Some nice fill;  thanks for giving me Creep, Video Games and Need You Tonight as a delightful ear worm mashup. And for making me mix up Pilgrim with VIRGIL and wondering why the former didn’t fit. 

Yet the whole didn’t gel for me. My problem, not yours,  dear constructor. Always in awe, not always on the same wave length.
Agree with Sam - excellent Sunday puzzle!
I am always amazed by the puzzles. There is NO way I could put them together. But I love solving them. Thanks!

This one took me longer than most Sundays due to a handful of sticky areas. 

I caught on to the theme early on without looking at the title when I figured out how to parse GRANDRAPIDS. Not familiar with those rappers, but understanding the concept of rap music and names in general, and having filled in most of the answer from crosses, was able to suss it out. Figuring out each one thereafter was a little hit of dopamine. 

By the end, I was stuck in four places and kept having to switch out letters methodically in each area to get them: 

RECTO/BAIUL/CIAO - Didn't know RECTO and didn't remember how to spell Ms. BAIUL's name so had a Y instead of I for quite a while, and not knowing the Italian, didn't get CIAO at first. 

DOM/AVOCET - Didn't know the bird and still didn't understand DOM, but I'll go look it up as soon as I'm done writing this, unless someone wants to jump in and enlighten me. (Is it that kind of monk? The enlightenment kind?)

ROLEO/ALOU - I actually had this correct but thought maybe I was wrong when I didn't get the finished message. I remembered ALOU from a previous puzzle, but not knowing ROLEO, I thought maybe I misremembered it and tried different letters for L.

AENEAS/SAWEETIE - This was purely a spelling issue. Had AENEuS/SuWEETIE for far too long. 

I half considered looking some things up but resisted temptation and finally got the right combination. A satisfying puzzle!
I've been away from the puzzles for quite a while. What a welcome back puzzle! It is one of my all-timw favorites. Kudos to Garrett Chalfin.
Wow, 23:50 for that fun puzzle -- I feel almost invincible now!  Funny how if you sit with things long enough, the answers sort of bubble up.  Great construction today!

Enjoyable puzzle. Another reminder to check the title before I start! 

I’m curious whether 116A (ERUPT, clued with “Blow”) was an intentional homage to Mount Saint Helens? Today is the 35th anniversary of its eruption in 1980. It was a Sunday morning then, as well!🌋
Fun Sunday word play with enough little challenges to wake the brain. Thanks Garrett!

Second Sunday puzzle in a row that is chock full of arcane trivia. As a daily puzzler for over a decade, it’s disappointing to see grids with 20%+ clues that are either answered instantly or will remain blank without a Google search. I count 31 in today’s puzzle.
Great puzzle, my favourite of the year.  Every time I solved one of the theme clues I laughed out load.  Thanks Mr. Chalfin!

The author and editor of the puzzle are displayed before those of us online press play. Why not the puzzle name too? That we halve to check it manually is just poor interface design!

[Emus aren't real]
I liked the themed answers a lot but the rest of the grid was a bit trivia-heavy for me. Absolutely adored GROUCHOMARXMUSTACHE and WHATSTHEDAMAGE though

“Puba” and  “Daddy I.U”

[woosh!]

I enjoyed it but I still have no idea what

BIALY
E
A
R

is about. 

Had to reveal the B.

Fun!

ALOU crossed with ROLEO was my only quibble.

All right - first things first. 

Writing, "Laurel and Hardy, a comedy duo..." is like captioning a photo of a five dollar bill with, "Abraham Lincoln, a president..." Sheesh.

I was not surprised when my completed grid did not generate the happy music. I had, I think, five guesses at problematic crosses. What did surprise me was I only needed one lookup, SAWEETIE, to earn my gold star. I guessed wisely today. Thanks for the fun!

So I was driving up Main Street in Lake Placid, looking for a parking space, and my sister cried out, "Oh my God, that's Oksana BAIUL!" And there she was on the sidewalk heading to the ice rink. So I had that going for me today. And I did know AVOCET is a wading bird. but I think they're mostly on the West Coast. Much more likely to see Yellowlegs at the CAPE.
HAP for [Chance]?  I'm clueless.
Need explanation for 78 down.
MAKING AN IMP ACT! I snorted so loud!
Nice theme. But overall, I felt like I was playing Trivial Pursuit! Not my favorite Sunday.

Count me as one who forgot to remember the title before solving. I managed to figure out the theme without realizing the "last word" element. I had never heard of a BIALY, so I made a lucky guess there, informed by speculation that Mel Brooks may have picked Bialystock as a character name for The Producers as some kind of Yiddish inside joke.
Classicist in me had VeRGIL initially and eNXS seemed likely enough since I'm too young to know INXS

Great puzzle!

Anyone else playing Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 and perk up right away on seeing Verso?

I somehow got it in my head that it was GROUCHO’s something that MUST ACHE…so I kept trying to figure out what that “something” was…his lip, his arm, his eye. Held me up for a long time. Sometimes IMAMORON.
Finally got the solve in the SE when I realized I’M A MORON because “I’m so dumb” didn’t work. Nice puzzle
No Emus

In the New World, the Pilgrims first landed on . . .
a CAPE.
which CAPE?
THE CAPE.
Before, or after the Rotary?
Clumsy cluing.

As I recall, Caitlin, Mrs. Who's dialogue wasn't particularly riddle-laden. She did pepper her speech with a lot of quotations from world literature--cited in the original languages in the novel, translated in the 2018 film (where she is played by Mindy Kaling.)
She also wears glasses, which become an important prop in the plot.
AENEAS is the son of Venus, because it's a Roman epic, written in Latin. Aphrodite is the OG, the Greek. (I am reliably informed by my spouse.)

Fun solve! I need two hands to count the fills I didn't know in this puzzle. RECTO and BAIUL had me stuck, but I figured out ROLEO, OLLAS, AVOCETS, in LOCO parentis, RHODA, etc. from the crossers. Sunday puzzles are a great way to learn new words, I guess. Fortunately I knew both, but I can definitely see the world where someone gets Naticked by B(I)ALY/(I)MPEI - bit of a nasty cell.
BIALY got me.

@Matthew O

Not to criticize; I know you don’t follow baseball in NZ, but you would be well served for crossword purposes to learn the name ALOU. It has appeared 262 times, most recently on Thursday. 

The ALOU brothers, Matty, Felipe and Jesús, all played in the 60s and 70s; Felipe’s son Moisës later followed in his footsteps. All were outfielders and all were star players. The three brothers were the first and only trio of brothers ever to play outfield for the same team at the same time in a game, in 1963. 

But for crosswords, their greatest achievement was having three vowels in a four-letter last name. 

Ironically, ALOU wasn’t even their normally accepted surname. That was Rojas. ALOU was their mother’s last name, and in Spanish naming tradition, the mother’s surname follows the father’s surname (e.g. Felipe Rojas ALOU), with the father’s surname being the everyday surname. When they came to the US, their surnames were misunderstood, and they started going by ALOU. 

And the rest is crossword—and baseball—history.

Of course, it's a bit personal for me as I was hump material in that era.  I believe my high school class had a few die in service in the following years.

Oddly, I never had to take a deferment of any kind.  I hated paper work so was dreading applying for one, but I was born just a year or so on the lucky side.

@Francis Someone might be able to do something with Alvar Aalto, a Finnish architect—five letters first name, five letters last name. An architect I knew said when he worked in Aalto's atelier in Helsinki, the director Michelangelo Antonioni had visited one day and commissioned Aalto to design a floor lamp for him. Erik, dreaming of meeting Antonioni's partner and muse the beautiful actress Monica Vitti, offered to deliver the lamp in Rome. He said he was so afraid the lamp might be damaged during the flight that he kept it with him in the cabin. The next day, carefully dressed and tonsured, he took the lamp to Antonioni's apartment, almost trembling in anticipation of meeting the gorgeous Monica, and rang the doorbell. A maid answered the door, Erik introduced himself and explained about the lamp. The maid took the lamp, thanked him, and closed the door. Not even a glimpse of Monica Vitti. He laughed when he told the story, but I suspect a tiny bit of disappointment still lingered. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alvar_Aalto

Verso and RECTO are printing terms that I learned years ago. Verso is the left-hand page of an open book and (as you might guess), recto is the right-hand page. Why the Latin? I guess the book makers didn’t want doctors and lawyers to have all the fun. 

Yes, the puzzle’s theme had some groaners, but I was amused by a few of the theme answers. Sorry you weren’t.

@Andrzej

I fared OK with the fill, getting the unknowns on the crosses. But I'm with you on those puns.
They were really hard puns to find, given the structure imposed by the theme, so kudos to the constructor for that. And it's not that I don't like puns ...

But Theodore Bernstein made a useful distinction between good puns and bad puns in his (now somewhat outdated by still excellent) book "Miss Thistlebottom's Hobgoblins: The Careful Writer's Guide to the Taboos, Bugbears and Outmoded Rules of English Usage".
Just by the nature of the theme, these were pretty much fated to fall into Bernstein's category of disposable groaners, rather than puns for the ages. (That's me editorializing, by the way, not Bernstein's original words.)

That's fine, though. I'd have preferred something involving rebuses or contorted fill, but lots of people seem to hate that sort of thing. So I just winced my way through, and once I understood the rules, the theme gave me some fill I might otherwise have hung up on. I was glad to get it over with, though.

@CB As a student in Vienna in 1970, a bunch of us visited Krakow. We were warned to first speak English, then French, and then German as a last resort to make it clear we weren't German so that the waiters didn't spit in our drinks or "accidentally" spill the soup on top of our heads.

@Marcia Fidler

There is very little hate towards Germans here these days. We have been peaceful neighbors for decades, and most of us appreciate it. I've never seen any Germans being treated badly anywhere, and I am usually welcomed warmly in Germany, as a Pole.

We remember our histories, of course, but we have learned from them. I think of the horror of Warsaw's destruction with the same sadness as when I consider the plight of Dresden, or Nuremberg, or other German cities.

If anybody may expect any outright hostility, it's Russians, but even so I haven't heard of any violence against them.

@Mark

I’m sorry to hear that you had to struggle with OCD in your younger days. I’m glad that you’re better now. 

Thanks for the reminder that May is Mental Health Awareness Month. I was surprised to learn earlier today that this goes back to 1949. 

As some Wordplay readers know, my father and three of my siblings — Mark, Sharon and Kurt — died from Huntington’s Disease or related causes. It was painful to see them struggle with the cognitive and emotional challenges of HD such as delusions, depression, anxiety and obsessive behavior.

I’m fortunate that I didn’t get the genetic mutation that causes HD. But I have had my own mental health issues, including a period about 10 years ago when I often thought about suicide. I’m thankful that that period is over. 

If you know someone who needs help with a mental health issue, please do what you can to see that they get professional help. No one should have to try to deal with those issues alone. 

Thank you.

@Mark

I'm glad you're doing well and can enjoy your life.

Two of my siblings struggle terribly with OCD, so I cringe as well when people make light of it.  

It's good to see people talk about their struggles, though.  It removes some of the undeserved shame that people deal with.

@Eric Hougland

Thank you for your kind words, and for sharing the plight of your family. I am glad you have been spared the condition, but I know how difficult it is to cope when surrounded by such suffering.

My family has been beset with mental illness for many generations. My grandmother committed suicide on NYE, so this puzzle, as benign as it can be, had several triggers for me.

I hope others will weigh in. It is good to get things out and raise awareness.

@Nancy J.

Thank you, Nancy. And thanks for contributing to the conversation. OCD is a fairly common affliction, but many who have it are embarrassed. I used to wonder if the neighbors were watching me go back to my house for the umpteenth time. It was humiliating.

@Mark and @Eric and @Nancy J.
Wonderful to see these posts.  As a teacher and as a mother with children who had 'challenges' I came to know a number of other families who worked (and struggled) to help their offspring in the face of social stigma, health insurance strictures, and general life issues.  I was sincere in assuring myself and others that there IS a place for everyone.  The son of a friend worked at the university radio station, and if a program was to start at 2:01 a.m., believe me, that OCD kid had it On The Dot.  They loved him!

@Ben Biggs FWIW I haven't done a Google (or other online) search on crossword clues in over two years, but have a 99.3% puzzle completion rate (out of 1125 puzzles) despite not being familiar with quite a lot of the "arcane trivia". (I'm 55 years old, FWIW.)

Some of the answers I wasn't familiar with or sure of and had to get from crossings in today's puzzles, for example: 1A, 23A, 34A, 57A, 94A, 102A, 13D, 33D, 55D, 68D, 97D, 107D. Maybe one or two of these could be considered"arcane trivia", but certainly not all of them.

@Cindy

I solve either in the NYT Games app or on the NYT website.

In the app, I have to click the i to see the puzzle title.

On the website, I go to the main Games page and click on "Play" for the crossword. That opens the puzzle and give me an additional (unnecessary) window in which to click. In that window is the puzzle's title when there is one.

I never have to see the Wordplay column until I'm ready to see it (which is only when I've solved the puzzle).

Does that sound different than what you see?

@Barry Ancona

The title (if any) appears before the play on the website version.

@Eric Hougland

Yep! In the app, we only get the date, constructor, and editor before hitting Play, which opens the grid. We can only see the title by hitting the "i".

@Cindy

Sorry, but I don't see that as that big a problem. Yes, it would be nice to not have to click the i. 

But it would also be nice to not have to click three things jut to play or view a game.

And it would be even nicer to not have to click on a timestamp to see a reply that might not even be there.

@Eric Hougland

Maybe I meant "nope." Same digital experience to be sure. I guess I just miss getting the Magazine and reading the title and notes before starting the solve.

@JayTee It's nice of you to mention this to folks, but I hope the devs here will acknowledge that the information should be shared with users by default, given similar to how it is in print. And we should have the option to remove the share if we don't like it. 

Although this might seem like a trivial consideration from the perspective of one person, think of the implication of one second of frustration and wasted time per user over thousands of users over years puzzling. The collective inconvenience adds up.
